column5: the second-largest city on the German Baltic coast and in the state of Schleswig-Holstein
column7: and it is the 35th-largest city in Germany. The city lies in Holstein
column9: on the mouth of the River Trave
column10: which flows into the Bay of Lübeck in the borough of Travemünde
column11: and on the Trave's tributary Wakenitz. The Elbe–Lübeck Canal
column12: which connects the Baltic to the Elbe River at Lauenburg
column13: also crosses the city. Lübeck is surrounded by the lakes of the Lauenburg Lakes Nature Park in the southeast
column14: and the lakes of Wagria in the northwest. The city is part of the Hamburg Metropolitan Region
column15: and is the southwesternmost city on the Baltic
column16: as well as the closest point of access to the Baltic from Hamburg. The port of Lübeck is the second-largest German Baltic port after the port of Rostock. There is a regional airport in the southern borough of Blankensee. The city lies in the Northern Low Saxon dialect area of Low German.

column1: Lübeck had once been founded as the Slavic village Liubice
column2: and its name is of Slavic origin. The city is famous for having been the cradle and the de facto capital of the Hanseatic League. Its city centre is Germany's most extensive UNESCO World Heritage Site. While the city's symbol is the Holsten Gate
column3: Lübeck's skyline is dominated by the seven towers of its five main churches St Mary's
column4: Lübeck Cathedral
column5: St Jacob's
column9: was the first large brickwork church in the Baltic region. St Mary's
column11: served as model for the other Brick Gothic churches around the Baltic. It has the second-tallest two-steeples façade after Cologne Cathedral
column14: and is the second-tallest brickwork structure after St Martin's in Landshut. Travemünde is a famous seaside resort
column15: and its Maritim high-rise serves as the second-tallest lighthouse in the world at 114 metres high. Lübeck is also known for Lübeck Marzipan.

column1: Humans settled in the area around what today is Lübeck after the last Ice Age ended about 9700 BCE. Several Neolithic dolmens can be found in the area.

column2: Slavic peoples started moving into the eastern parts of Holstein
column3: an area previously settled by Germanic inhabitants who had moved on in the Migration Period. Charlemagne (Holy Roman Emperor 800–814)
column4: whose efforts to Christianise the area were opposed by the Germanic Saxons
column5: expelled many of the Saxons and brought in Polabian Slavs allies. Liubice (the place-name means "lovely") was founded on the banks of the River Trave about  4 km (2.5 mi) north of the present-day city-center of Lübeck. In the 10th century
column6: it became the most important settlement of the Obotrite confederacy and a castle was built. In 1128
column7: the pagan Rani from Rügen razed Liubice.

column4: founded the modern town as a German settlement on the river island of Bucu.  He built a new castle
column5: first mentioned by the chronicler Helmold as existing in 1147.  Adolf had to cede the castle to the Duke of Saxony
column7: in 1158.  After Henry's fall from power in 1181
column8: the town became an Imperial city for eight years. Emperor Barbarossa (reigned 1152–1190) ordained that the city should have a ruling council of 20 members.  With the council dominated by merchants
column9: pragmatic trade interests shaped Lübeck's politics for centuries.  The council survived into the 19th century.  The town and castle changed ownership for a period afterwards and formed part of the Duchy of Saxony until 1192
column10: of the County of Holstein until 1217
column11: and of the kingdom of Denmark until the Battle of Bornhöved in 1227.

column2: the port became the main point of departure for colonists leaving for the Baltic territories conquered by the Livonian Order
column4: by the Teutonic Order. In 1226
column5: Emperor Frederick II elevated the town to the status of an Imperial free city
column6: by which it became the Free City of Lübeck.

column2: Lübeck became the "Queen of the Hanseatic League"
column3: being by far the largest and most powerful member of that medieval trade organization. In 1375
column4: Emperor Charles IV named Lübeck one of the five "Glories of the Empire"
column5: a title shared with Venice

column1: Several conflicts about trading privileges resulted in fighting between Lübeck (with the Hanseatic League) and Denmark and Norway – with varying outcome. While Lübeck and the Hanseatic League prevailed in conflicts in 1435 and 1512
column2: Lübeck lost when it became involved in the Count's Feud
column3: a civil war that raged in Denmark from 1534 to 1536. Lübeck also joined the pro-Lutheran Schmalkaldic League of the mid-16th century.

column1: After its defeat in the Count's Feud
column2: Lübeck's power slowly declined. The city remained neutral in the Thirty Years' War of 1618–1648
column3: but the combination of the devastation from the decades-long war and the new transatlantic orientation of European trade caused the Hanseatic League – and thus Lübeck with it – to decline in importance. However
column4: even after the de facto disbanding of the Hanseatic League in 1669
column5: Lübeck still remained an important trading town on the Baltic Sea.

column1: Franz Tunder was the organist in the Marienkirche. It was part of the tradition in this Lutheran congregation that the organist would pass on the duty in a dynastic marriage. In 1668
column2: his daughter Anna Margarethe married the great Danish-German composer Dieterich Buxtehude
column3: who was the organist at the Marienkirche in Lübeck until at least 1703. Some of the greatest composers of the day came to the church to hear his renowned playing.

column1: In the course of the war of the Fourth Coalition against Napoleon
column2: troops under Bernadotte (who would later become King of Sweden) occupied the neutral Lübeck after a battle against Blücher on 6 November 1806. Under the Continental System
column3: the State bank went into bankruptcy. In 1811
column4: the French Empire formally annexed Lübeck as part of France; the anti-Napoleonic allies liberated the area in 1813
column5: and the Congress of Vienna of 1815 recognised Lübeck as an independent free city. The city became a member of the German Confederation (1815-1866) the North German Confederation (1866-1871) the German Empire (1871-1918) and the Weimar Republic (1919-1933).

The battle was to become the founding myth of the last Lübeck regiment

Under the Third Reich (1933-1945) the Nazis passed the Greater Hamburg Act
column2: which incorporated the city of Lübeck into the Schleswig-Holstein province of Prussia
column4: 1937. It thereby lost its status as an independent constituent state.

column1: Writer Thomas Mann was a member of the Mann family of Lübeck merchants. His well-known 1901 novel Buddenbrooks made readers in Germany (and later worldwide
column2: through numerous translations) familiar with the manner of life and mores of the 19th-century Lübeck bourgeoisie.

Lübeck became the first German city to suffer substantial Royal Air Force (RAF) bombing. The attack of 28 March 1942 created a firestorm that caused severe damage to the historic centre. This raid destroyed three of the main churches and large parts of the built-up area; the bells of St Marienkircke plunged to the stone floor. Germany operated a prisoner-of-war camp for officers
column4: near the city from 1940 until April 1945. The British Second Army entered Lübeck on 2 May 1945 and occupied it without resistance.

column2: one of the biggest disasters in naval history occurred in the Bay of Lübeck when RAF bombers sank three ships: the SS Cap Arcona
column4: and the SS Thielbek – which

Lübeck remained part of Schleswig-Holstein after World War II (and consequently lay within West Germany). It stood directly on what became the inner German border during the division of Germany into two states in the Cold War period. South of the city
column6: the border followed the path of the river Wakenitz
column7: which separated the Germanys by less than 10 m (32.81 ft) in many parts. The northernmost border crossing was in Lübeck's district of Schlutup. Lübeck spent decades restoring its historic city centre. In 1987
column8: UNESCO designated this area a World Heritage Site.

column1: Lübeck became the scene of a notable art scandal in the 1950s. Lothar Malskat was hired to restore the medieval frescoes of the cathedral of the Marienkirche

column4: which he passed off as restorations
column5: fooling many experts. Malskat later revealed the deception himself. Günter Grass featured this incident in his 1986 novel The Rat.

column2: a fire broke out in a home for foreign refugees
column3: killing 10 people and severely injuring more than 30 others
column4: mostly children. Most of the shelter's inhabitants thought it was a racist attack
column5: as they stated that they had encountered other overt hostility in the city. The police and the local court were criticized at the time for ruling out racism as a possible motive before even beginning preliminary investigations. But by 2002
column6: the courts found all the Germans involved not guilty; the perpetrators have not been caught.

column1: In 2019 Lübeck reached 2 million overnight stays. Lübeck is famous for its medieval City Center with the Churches
column3: its small alleys and so much more. Lübeck has been called "Die Stadt der 7 Türme" (The City of seven Towers) due to its seven prominent church towers.

column1: Lübeck is connected to three Main Motorways (Autobahnen). The A1 Motorway is heading north to the Island of Fehmarn and Copenhagen (Denmark) and south to Hamburg
column2: Bremen and Cologne. The A20 Motorway is heading east to Wismar
column3: Rostock and Szczecin (Poland) and west to Bad Segeberg and to the North Sea. The A226 Motorway starts in Central Lübeck and is heading to the north-east and the Seaport-City of Travemünde.

column1: Lübeck has multiple train Stations. The biggest of them is Lübeck Central Station. With about 31.000 passengers per day
column2: it's the largest station in Schleswig-Holstein. The station is most likely being served by regional rail services to Hamburg
column4: Kiel
column5: The Island of Fehmarn and Szczecin (Poland). There are some Long-distance trains to Munich
column6: Frankfurt a.M. and Cologne. During the summer holidays
column7: there are many extra rail services. Till the end of 2019
column8: Lübeck was a stop on the "Vogelfluglinie" train line from Hamburg to Copenhagen (Denmark).

column1: Public transport by bus is organized by the Lübeck City-Traffic-Company (Lübecker Stadtverkehr). There are 40 buslines serving the city and the area around Lübeck. There are some other regional Bus services.

In Lübeck's district of Travemünde is on the Baltic Sea and has the city's main port. The Scandinavienkai (the quay of Scandinavia) has ferry routes to Malmo and Trelleborg (Sweden); Liepaja (Latvia); Helsinki (Finland) and St.Petersburg (Russia). It is the second-biggest German port on the Baltic Sea.
Lübeck Airport is located in the south of Lübeck in the Town of Blankensee. It provides regional flights to Munich and Stuttgart and some charter flights to Italy and Croatia.
